data.title: MEDCoE (US Army Medical Center of Excellence) on LinkedIn: #medcoe #armymedicinestartshere
authors: MEDCoE (US Army Medical Center of Excellence)
data.meta_description: Please join us as the 32d Medical Brigade Change of Command Ceremony as COL Marc R. Welde will relinquish the 32d Medical Brigade to COL Jason C. Williams on…
data.text:
Students attending the medical Basic Officer Leadership Course #BOLC cool off by inserting their arms in an Arm Immersion Cooling Station (AICS) at Camp Bullis, TX. AICS works to cool the body through the process of convection and conduction. Heat transfers from the hot arms and the circulating blood to the cooler water. The cooled blood flows back to the core to extract additional body heat and reaches the arms again to continue the same cycle. Under direct supervision, soldiers immerse their hands and forearms into cool water (below 80 degrees Fahrenheit). The soldier is timed with a stopwatch by the cadre utilizing the U.S. Army Training and Doctrine Command immersion chart. Soldiers pump their legs to increase blood flow while dunking to increase circulation. Once the time has elapsed, the Soldier will raise their hands up in the air and walk away. This is one of the preventative safety measures along with hydration, misting fans, ice sheets, and rest periods measures #MEDCoE is taking to students and cadre mitigate against the heat during field training exercises. #ArmyMedicineStartsHere #ArmySafety #TRADOC #USACAC #ArmyMedicine #JBSA #32dMEDBDE #187thMEDBN

After more than a week of grueling challenges, our MEDCoE Team took Third Place in the #TRADOCBestSquad competition! We are so proud of this outstanding team and their hard work! This is the first time MEDCoE has placed in this competition. Well done, Team! Hooah! Let's hear it for Sgt 1st Class Joshua Manley, 232d Medical Battalion Sgt. Sean Bailey, 188th Medical Battalion Spc. Conor Pilcher, 188th Medical Battalion Spc. Matthew Wakefield, 188th Medical Battalion Spc. Evan LeHoux, 188th Medical Battalion Photos of our team: https://lnkd.in/gjj3tvtN Photos and videos of the competition: https://lnkd.in/gbpppYZg #StrengthenTheProfession #DevelopLeaders US Army TRADOC U.S. Army Combined Arms Center

This week’s Med Minute continues exploring the doctrine of Tactical Combat Care. MSG Chesterton takes us through the Phases of TC3. If you enjoyed our Med Minutes installment, please follow, or subscribe for future installments. The complete collection can be found at https://lnkd.in/g7RhMAis. Would you like to develop Med Minutes for your own specialty? Contact MEDCOE Learning Technology and Multimedia Division at: usarmy.jbsa.medical-coe.mbx.distributed-learning@army.mil. #MedMInutes

187th Medical Battalion is at it again! Soldiers and civilians of the 187th Medical Battalion reaffirmed their commitment to Briscoe Elementary School by signing their Adopt-A-School charter before handing out much-needed school supplies to students and their families. https://lnkd.in/gVbsusWN The 187th Medical Battalion has participated in the Fort Sam Houston Adopt-A-School program for over nine years by sponsoring supply drives, holiday gifts donations and sports days. They also mentor students by visiting the school throughout the school year. San Antonio ISD #GiveBack #AdoptASchool #ThisWellDefend

The latest group of 68C, Army Practical Nursing Specialists, graduated from phase II of their training at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. 68Cs spend their first 11 weeks of training here in the 264th Medical Battalion before they move on to their phase II training sites. We are extremely proud of how hard these Soldiers work to maintain a first-time licensing pass rate of more than 90 percent, higher than the national average. Read more here: https://lnkd.in/gth4B_uf #DevelopLeaders #ModernizeTheTrainingBase US Army TRADOC U.S. Army Combined Arms Center Walter Reed National Military Medical Center
